content_zh-Hans: Coding Project: LogClusterC
C-based implementation of the LogCluster algorithm, a density-based data clustering algorithm for event logs, introduced by Risto Vaarandi and Mauno Pihelgas in 2015.
<iframe class="embeddedvideo" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/433554834" width="640" height="360" frameborder="1" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Features:
  • Performance oriented: 30GB log files' patterns can be discovered within 30 minutes
  • String hash table and prefix tree, optimized for both performance and memory consumption
  • 24 supported command-line options: basic analytics and advanced heuristics
  • Abnormality (outlier events) detection
  • Regular expression support
  • Three levels of verbosity for console output
href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1X0Kv1O9mHvxNCU2XaVkYsafQ_KPFg2kF?usp=sharing"
Executable Download (Google Drive)
Code Repository (GitHub)
Project Related Content: Conference Paper (short)
Project Related Content: Thesis (long)
content_en: Coding Project: LogClusterC
C-based implementation of the LogCluster algorithm, a density-based data clustering algorithm for event logs, introduced by Risto Vaarandi and Mauno Pihelgas in 2015.
<iframe class="embeddedvideo" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/433554834" width="640" height="360" frameborder="1" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Features:
  • Performance oriented: 30GB log files' patterns can be discovered within 30 minutes
  • String hash table and prefix tree, optimized for both performance and memory consumption
  • 24 supported command-line options: basic analytics and advanced heuristics
  • Abnormality (outlier events) detection
  • Regular expression support
  • Three levels of verbosity for console output
href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1X0Kv1O9mHvxNCU2XaVkYsafQ_KPFg2kF?usp=sharing"

content_zh-Hans: Course Taken: ITX8070 Information Systems Attacks and Defense

Lecturer: Kaur Kasak
Place: Tallinn University of Technology
Course duration: 12 weeks (104 hours of study)
Mark: 4 (Lab Results + Written Exam)

On completion of the course the student has:
  • knowledge about common attack methods and vulnerabilities of information systems
  • knowledge about technological defense methods against cyber attacks
  • practical experience in conducting penetration tests of (lab) systems
Lab Notes: Scanning, MITM, Credential Attaks, Code Injection, SQLI, XSS, etc.
Bonus Lab Notes: Stack Overflow
content_en: Course Taken: ITX8070 Information Systems Attacks and Defense

Lecturer: Kaur Kasak
Place: Tallinn University of Technology
Course duration: 12 weeks (104 hours of study)
Mark: 4 (Lab Results + Written Exam)

On completion of the course the student has:
  • knowledge about common attack methods and vulnerabilities of information systems
  • knowledge about technological defense methods against cyber attacks
  • practical experience in conducting penetration tests of (lab) systems
Lab Notes: Scanning, MITM, Credential Attaks, Code Injection, SQLI, XSS, etc.
Bonus Lab Notes: Stack Overflow

content_zh-Hans: Course Taken: ITX8071 Cyber Defense Monitoring Solutions

Lecturer: Risto Vaarandi
Place: Tallinn University of Technology
Course duration: 16 weeks (156 hours of study)
Mark: 5 (100/100)

On completion of the course the student:
  • has an overview of the principles and standards of log collecting (BSD and IETF syslog)
  • can tune the UNIX logging software syslogd, rsyslog ja syslog-ng
  • is able to filter the network packets and generate log messages using netfilter firewall
  • knows different dialects of the regular expression languages (ERE, Perl) and is able to use these in the log monitoring
  • has an overview of the event correlation principles
  • is able to correlate events using Simple Event Correlator and use it for discovering and responding to attacks using different correlation techniques
  • has an overview of the network-based intrusion detection and prevention systems (network IDS/IPS)
  • is able to use Snort for intrusion detection and prevention
Assignment: event correlation rules used in Simple Event Correlator.
Assignment: event correlation rules used in Simple Event Correlator.
Test: firewall configuration, regular expression and event correlation rules.
Assignments and Tests
content_en: Course Taken: ITX8071 Cyber Defense Monitoring Solutions

Lecturer: Risto Vaarandi
Place: Tallinn University of Technology
Course duration: 16 weeks (156 hours of study)
Mark: 5 (100/100)

On completion of the course the student:

  • can tune the UNIX logging software syslogd, rsyslog ja syslog-ng
  • is able to filter the network packets and generate log messages using netfilter firewall
  • knows different dialects of the regular expression languages (ERE, Perl) and is able to use these in the log monitoring
  • has an overview of the event correlation principles
  • is able to correlate events using Simple Event Correlator and use it for discovering and responding to attacks using different correlation techniques
  • has an overview of the network-based intrusion detection and prevention systems (network IDS/IPS)
  • is able to use Snort for intrusion detection and prevention
Assignment: event correlation rules used in Simple Event Correlator.
Assignment: event correlation rules used in Simple Event Correlator.
Test: firewall configuration, regular expression and event correlation rules.
Assignments and Tests

content_zh-Hans: Coding Project: Simple Process Manager
A simple process manager for Windows.

Features:
  • Process: terminate, increase/decrease priority
  • Thread: terminate, suspend, resume
  • Virtual memory: base address, size, access protection
  • Modules: name, path, base address, unload
  • CPU information and usage curve
  • Physical memory information and usage curve
  • Windows enumeration
href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1tvMn8uuST9mfevXz1v972taTqs-nn36U?usp=sharing"
Executable Download (Google Drive)
Code Repository (GitHub)
content_en: Coding Project: Simple Process Manager
A simple process manager for Windows.

Features:
  • Process: terminate, increase/decrease priority
  • Thread: terminate, suspend, resume
  • Virtual memory: base address, size, access protection
  • Modules: name, path, base address, unload
  • CPU information and usage curve
  • Physical memory information and usage curve
  • Windows enumeration
href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1tvMn8uuST9mfevXz1v972taTqs-nn36U?usp=sharing"
Executable Download (Google Drive)
Code Repository (GitHub)

content_zh-Hans: Coding Project: x86 Disassembler

Intel x86 disassembler. A project done during the process of learning x86 Assembly.
Reference: Appendix A OPCODE MAP in Intel 64 and IA-32 Architectures Software Developer's Manual
<iframe class="embeddedvideo" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/432441815" width="640" height="360" frameborder="1" allow="autoplay; fullscreen" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Features:
  • Copy the opcode into the 'input.txt' file, and the disassembler will output the result to the console and the 'output.txt' file.
  • One-byte Opcode coverage: 100%
  • Two-byte Opcode coverage: 90% (the popular ones), including 0F00; 0F80-0F8F; 0F90-0F9F; 0FB6, 0FB7; 0FBE, 0FBF; 0FAF;
  • Three-byte Opcode coverage: None
href="https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/185WiQ4llzK_Ar2VrQnO8W0d6DcfrJLf3?usp=sharing"
Executable Download (Google Drive)
Code Repository (GitHub)

content_zh-Hans: Course Taken: ITV8040 MTAT.08.004 Network Technology

Lecturer: Truls Tuxen Ringkjob, Erkki Kukk
Place: Tallinn University of Technology, University of Tartu
Course duration: 32 weeks (312 hours of study)

On completing the course a student:
  • can install, operate and troubleshoot medium sized routed and switched networks
  • can implement and troubleshoot various protocols to manage addressing
  • is able to perform load balancing and authentication
  • is able to establish and troubleshoot connection to service provider over WAN
  • is prepared for CCNA (Cisco Certified Network Associate) certification exam
Lab Manual: DHCP Configuration
Lab Manual: NAT Configuration
Lab Notes

content_zh-Hans: Course Taken: ITX 8060 Malware

Lecturer: Toomas Lepik
Place: Tallinn University of Technology
Course duration: 16 weeks (156 hours of study)

Upon completion a student has:
  • understanding of different types of malware
  • skills to choose tools for detecting malware
  • understanding of static and dynamic approaches of malware analysis
  • skills to apply preventive methods
  • understanding of binary and program execution, reverse engineering, and anti-RE measures
Lab Report: Random Malware Exploration
Lab Report: USB Flash Drive Data Restoration
Lab Report: Malware in an Infected System Image
Lab Report: Malware Match Using Yara and MD5

content_zh-Hans: Course Taken: LOOM.02.331 GIS, Maps and Spatial Analyses in Urban Planning

Lecturer: Anto Aasa
Place: University of Tartu
Course duration: 4 weeks (52 hours of study)

Upon completion of the course, the student will be able:
  • to understand and describe the need for, and the nature and content of the urban planning
  • to describe and use the databases, software and formats available for the spatial analysis
  • to read visualizations related to the urban planning (maps, sketch, 3D models etc.) as well as to create these visualizations
Data Analytics and Visualization Exercises
Buffer Zone Simulation with R

content_zh-Hans: Course Taken: MTAT.08.021 System Administration

Lecturer: Artjom Lind
Place: University of Tartu
Course duration: 16 weeks (156 hours of study)

After this course students will have basic knowledge on the following topics:
  • Logical Volume Management
  • DNS and BIND settings
  • Mail: MX record, Postfix, Dovecot, Spamassassin
  • CNAME, Apache, MySQL, Web mail, phpmyadmin
  • Apache status module and limited access, Apache SSL, SNI
  • NFS server and client, Samba, Samba SWAT, Quota
  • Media Server: MediaTomb, CMS: WordPress
  • Version Control (SVN)
Notes: logical volume resize.
Notes: disk encryption.
Notes: IPv6 and setting up DNS Server.
Notes: setting up mail service.
In the process of lab3.
Catching up deadlines.
All 158 task checkpoints passed.
Notes and Screenshots
Results table Origin. The final exam was hands-on accessment in limited time. Two attempts were allowed, and the highest score was counted (full mark 70 pt).
Final Mark: 5 (92/100)

content_zh-Hans: Book Read: Mastering Microsoft Visual Basic 2010

Author: Evangelos Petroutsos
Publisher: Sybex; 1 edition (April 5, 2010)
Paperback: 1056 pages

Coverage:
  • Mastering VB programming essentials, including GUI design, event-driven programming, basic Windows controls
  • Working with custom classes, controls, and objects
  • Understanding the .NET framework, including XML, LINQ, and storing data in collections
  • Programming with ADO.NET, using the data entity model, and understanding DataSets
  • Building web applications and programming with web services
  • Getting the most out of advanced Windows controls such as ListView and TreeView controls

content_zh-Hans: 学过的课程: IDK1011 Introduction to Programming

Lecturer: Msury Rogasian Mahunnah
Place: Tallinn University of Technology
Course duration: 16 weeks (104 hours of study)

After completing the course, student should:
  • be familiar with algorithms creation
  • be able to create Scratch applications
  • be able to create simple programs using Python or VBA programming language
Assignment 1 requirements.

Assignment 1 deliverable screenshot. See the source code & Play this game online!

This work was inspired by the popular car parking games in the Scratch community. Though the Scratch environment is not for serious developing, this work encountered and solved two challenging problems:
1. Dynamic playground rendering. Most of the programs in the Scratch community are in a static canvas playground, while this program figured out a way to render a much bigger and dynamic playground for the racing cars. (Trick: User's blue car is always in the screen center, changing directions but never actually moving. In fact, the playground moves as opposed to the user input direction.)
2. Computer player simulation. The cars in red and yellow are simulated computer players, who participate the racing game by querying the stored route data and using random number generater.
Assignment 2 requirements.
Assignment 2 deliverable screenshot.
Assignment 2 deliverable code snippet: guessing the number. Full source code
Assignment 3 deliverable code snippet: filling user input to dynamic array. Full source code
Assignment 4 requirements.
Assignment 4 code snippet: (part of) the timer tick handler. Full source code
Assignments: Requirements, Screenshots, Code Snippets and Source Code
Results table
Final Mark: 5 (98/100)

Lecturer: Msury Rogasian Mahunnah
Place: Tallinn University of Technology

After completing the course, student should:
  • be familiar with algorithms creation
  • be able to create Scratch applications
  • be able to create simple programs using Python or VBA programming language
Assignment 1 requirements.

Assignment 1 deliverable screenshot. See the source code & Play this game online!

This work was inspired by the popular car parking games in the Scratch community. Though the Scratch environment is not for serious developing, this work encountered and solved two challenging problems:
1. Dynamic playground rendering. Most of the programs in the Scratch community are in a static canvas playground, while this program figured out a way to render a much bigger and dynamic playground for the racing cars. (Trick: User's blue car is always in the screen center, changing directions but never actually moving. In fact, the playground moves as opposed to the user input direction.)
2. Computer player simulation. The cars in red and yellow are simulated computer players, who participate the racing game by querying the stored route data and using random number generater.
